awd_titl_txt: Core Support for the Board on Environmental Change and Society (BECS) of the National Academies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will continue support for core operations of the Board on Environmental Change and Society (BECS) of the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences.  This board has functioned under its current and previous names since 1989 to advance science and environmental decision making by promoting integrated analysis of the human interactions with the natural environment.  BECS will work with government agencies and other sponsors build understanding of human interactions with the biophysical environment; contribute to the development of a coherent field of scientific endeavor in this area; integrate social and behavioral science research into environmental science and policy; advance the behavioral, social, and decision sciences; and provide benefits to society through the application of these sciences to manage human-environment interactions.  BECS will evaluate research simultaneously from the perspectives of the natural and social sciences with a focus on advancing generalizable knowledge to assist decision makers and improve the quality of practices at the federal, state, and local levels.  BECS also will facilitate the development of an interdisciplinary research community in response to an increased realization that global environmental issues require enhanced knowledge based on social science research.  Because it is responsive to and anticipatory in the advancement of cutting-edge science and application to policy to identifying innovative solutions to improve societal wellbeing, BECS serves as a national resource for the advancement of use-inspired science to inform decision makers, stakeholders, and communities addressing a myriad of environmental change challenges and opportunities.

The Board on Environmental Change and Society functions as the National Academies' primary unit for advancing research on the interactions between human activities and the environment by providing a forum for linking the social and natural sciences in research, planning, and decision making.  BECS will strive to integrate social, behavioral, and natural science knowledge to address emerging scientific and governmental concerns through workshops, consensus studies, semi-annual meetings, symposia, and a variety of outreach mechanisms.  Over the period to be supported with this award, BECS will develop and oversee activities, engage a greater breadth of stakeholders and serve as a focal point toward which federal agencies and other governmental and non-governmental decision makers look to for integrated, trans-disciplinary approaches to cross cutting environmental challenges and opportunities. BECS aims to advance new lines of interdisciplinary research on topics at the intersection of human and natural systems such as innovation in energy transitions and the social implications of such transitions; the nexus between food, energy, and water; building resilient and low-carbon cities; and shifts in migration under conditions of environmental change.

por.por_cntn:
The  Board on Environmental Change and Society (BECS), draws upon nationally and internationally recognized experts from varied scientific disciplines and practitioner communities to support its mission to advance understanding of human interactions with the biophysical environment; contribute to the development of a coherent field of scientific endeavor in this area; integrate social and behavioral science research into environmental science and policy; advance the behavioral, social, and decision sciences; and provide benefits to society through the application of these sciences to manage human-environment interactions. BECS presents a platform that does not exist elsewhere in the National Academies or within the government sector and scholarly community. The Board advances generalizable knowledge to assist decision makers and improve the quality of practices at the federal, state and local levels.  BECS facilitates the development of an interdisciplinary research community in response to an increased realization that addressing global environmental issues requires the incorporation of social and behavioral sciences alongside the natural sciences. The work of the Board and of its committees is subject to the National Academies’ high scientific standards for rigor, excellence, and peer review. 

 

BECS provides a standing presence for social sciences among programs of the National Academies that deal with environmental issues, to assure that social science knowledge and insights are integrated into their efforts to advise federal agencies and others on matters on environmental analysis and policy. As such, BECS is a focal point toward which federal agencies and other governmental and non-governmental decision makers may look for integrated, trans-disciplinary approaches to environmental issues. It is also a place where social and behavioral scientists can identify ways their research could be directed to help address challenges faced by environmental decision makers.

 

Major transitions are on the horizon for human-environment systems and relationships, on global to local scales. Changes in climate, sea level, land cover (urbanization, desertification, reforestation, etc.), biodiversity, water quality and availability, persistent pollutants (among other issues) all have consequences for human populations and their needs. These changes will interact with demographic trends, technological innovation, energy consumption, and patterns of economic and social development. In some cases, the transition to new conditions will be forced, immediate, and unplanned (e.g., resulting from an extreme event), but other transitions can be conducted with forethought. BECS can help inform both types of transitions by anticipating inductive natural and social factors and timing, by helping society understand the likely intended and unintended consequences of human responses, and by providing options for coping with undesirable environmental changes. Projects developed and carried out through this award reflect this focus and the emerging strategic plan of NASEM to accelerate climate action through its Climate Crossroads initiative, including tackling decarbonization, addressing health and equity concerns around climate change, and building adaptive and resilient communities to respond to future environmental change.
